G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 2\u20133.proposition: Venue is proper in Lynn District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 2–3, because the events and omissions giving rise to this claim occurred in Lynn, Essex County, Massachusetts, and the Premises are located within this Court’s territorial jurisdiction.

G.L. c. 143, \u00a7 3.proposition: Massachusetts law, including but not limited to G.L. c. 143, § 3, G.L. c. 148, §§ 26E, 26F, 26F½, and the State Building Code and State Fire Code (780 CMR; 527 CMR), requires owners of certain residential properties, such as multi-unit apartment buildings, to install and maintain operable smoke detectors in common hallways and areas to protect residents from fire-related harm.

G.L. c. 148, \u00a7\u00a7 26E.proposition: Massachusetts law, including but not limited to G.L. c. 143, § 3, G.L. c. 148, §§ 26E, 26F, 26F½, and the State Building Code and State Fire Code (780 CMR; 527 CMR), requires owners of certain residential properties, such as multi-unit apartment buildings, to install and maintain operable smoke detectors in common hallways and areas to protect residents from fire-related harm.

G.L. c. 148, \u00a7\u00a7 26F.proposition: Massachusetts law, including but not limited to G.L. c. 143, § 3, G.L. c. 148, §§ 26E, 26F, 26F½, and the State Building Code and State Fire Code (780 CMR; 527 CMR), requires owners of certain residential properties, such as multi-unit apartment buildings, to install and maintain operable smoke detectors in common hallways and areas to protect residents from fire-related harm.

G.L. c. 148, \u00a7\u00a7 26F\u00bd.proposition: Massachusetts law, including but not limited to G.L. c. 143, § 3, G.L. c. 148, §§ 26E, 26F, 26F½, and the State Building Code and State Fire Code (780 CMR; 527 CMR), requires owners of certain residential properties, such as multi-unit apartment buildings, to install and maintain operable smoke detectors in common hallways and areas to protect residents from fire-related harm.

780 CMR.proposition: Massachusetts law, including but not limited to G.L. c. 143, § 3, G.L. c. 148, §§ 26E, 26F, 26F½, and the State Building Code and State Fire Code (780 CMR; 527 CMR), requires owners of certain residential properties, such as multi-unit apartment buildings, to install and maintain operable smoke detectors in common hallways and areas to protect residents from fire-related harm.

527 CMR.proposition: Massachusetts law, including but not limited to G.L. c. 143, § 3, G.L. c. 148, §§ 26E, 26F, 26F½, and the State Building Code and State Fire Code (780 CMR; 527 CMR), requires owners of certain residential properties, such as multi-unit apartment buildings, to install and maintain operable smoke detectors in common hallways and areas to protect residents from fire-related harm.

Scott v. Simons, 345 Mass. 484 (1963).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, landlords and property owners owe a duty of reasonable care to tenants and lawful occupants with respect to the condition of common areas and building systems under their control.
Scott v. Simons, 345 Mass. 484 (1963).case_name: Zavaglia v. Contributory Retirement Appeal Board
Scott v. Simons, 345 Mass. 484 (1963).support_reasoning: The opinion is not Scott v. Simons and does not involve landlord-tenant duties or premises liability. It concerns a public employee’s disability retirement under G.L. c. 32, § 7, and interprets statutory terms such as “personal injury” and “definite time and place.” It therefore does not address or establish any rule about a landlord or property owner’s duty of reasonable care to tenants or lawful occupants in common areas or building systems.
Scott v. Simons, 345 Mass. 484 (1963).relevant_excerpt: “Present § 7 (1) reads: ‘…by reason of a personal injury sustained or a hazard undergone as a result of, and while in the performance of, his duties at some definite place and at some definite time….’ … The Legislature has made it plain by the 1945 amendment that its intention was to broaden the coverage, and that a personal injury, including one of a cumulative nature, is encompassed within the disability provisions of the statute.”

Humphrey v. Byron, 447 Mass. 322 (2006).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, landlords and property owners owe a duty of reasonable care to tenants and lawful occupants with respect to the condition of common areas and building systems under their control.
Humphrey v. Byron, 447 Mass. 322 (2006).support_reasoning: The case concerns commercial, not residential, premises and expressly declines to extend the Young v. Garwacki duty of reasonable care to commercial landlords. While the opinion quotes and reaffirms Young’s rule for residential lessors, its holding is that Massachusetts has not imposed that general duty on commercial landlords beyond common areas or areas over which they retain control. Thus, it does not support the broad proposition about landlords’ duties to tenants in common areas and building systems; it limits such duties in the commercial context.
Humphrey v. Byron, 447 Mass. 322 (2006).relevant_excerpt: Our decision today leaves intact the rule that “a lessor of commercial premises is liable in tort for personal injuries only if either (1) he contracted to make repairs and made them negligently, or (2) the defect that caused the injury was in a ‘common area,’ or other area appurtenant to the leased area, over which the lessor had some control.” Chausse v. Coz, 405 Mass. 264, 266 (1989).

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).proposition: Defendant, as the owner and operator of the Premises and as landlord to Plaintiff, owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care to keep the common areas, including hallways and life‑safety systems, in a reasonably safe condition.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).support_reasoning: The provided excerpt is a concurrence discussing the general move away from rigid entrant classifications (licensee/invitee/trespasser) and criticizing how trespassers are treated. It does not mention landlords, tenants, common areas, or life‑safety systems, nor does it articulate a specific landlord’s duty to maintain common areas in a reasonably safe condition. While Mounsey more broadly concerns occupier’s duties to entrants, this text alone does not clearly support the specific landlord‑tenant duty stated in the proposition.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).relevant_excerpt: The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a “licensee” rather than an “invitee,” or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors.

Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.proposition: Defendant, as the owner and operator of the Premises and as landlord to Plaintiff, owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care to keep the common areas, including hallways and life‑safety systems, in a reasonably safe condition.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.support_reasoning: The case discusses a landowner/lessor’s general duty of reasonable care to lawful entrants and the duty to maintain property in a reasonably safe condition, including the doctrine regarding open and obvious dangers and a duty to remedy. However, it does not address or frame the duty in terms specific to a landlord’s obligations for ‘common areas, including hallways and life‑safety systems.’ The opinion concerns a backyard setup (trampoline and pool) and does not involve common‑area or life‑safety‑system duties, so it does not directly support the more specific proposition stated.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.relevant_excerpt: “An owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises. This duty includes an obligation to maintain the ‘property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’ Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708 (1973). It also includes an obligation ‘to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware.’”

Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.raw_text: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc., 408 Mass. 355, 359–60 (1990)
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.proposition: Violation of statutes and regulations designed to protect the safety of building occupants, including fire and building codes pertaining to smoke detectors, constitutes evidence of negligence.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.case_name: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.support_reasoning: The court expressly states that violation of G.L. c. 138, § 69 (a safety-related statute governing alcohol service) is not negligence per se but is "some evidence" of negligence as to the harms the statute was intended to prevent. That principle is directly analogous to building and fire code violations: statutory and regulatory safety violations do not automatically establish negligence, but they constitute evidence of negligence. Thus the case supports the proposition that violations of occupant-safety statutes and regulations are evidence of negligence, not conclusive proof.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.relevant_excerpt: “It has long been the rule in this Commonwealth that violation of a statute does not by itself establish a breach of duty, for it does not constitute negligence per se. … Rather, violation of a statute such as § 69 is only ‘some evidence’ of the defendant's negligence as to all consequences the statute was intended to prevent. Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., supra. Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 498, 499 (1968).”

LaClair v. Silberline Mfg. Co., 379 Mass.raw_text: LaClair v. Silberline Mfg. Co., 379 Mass. 21 (1979)
LaClair v. Silberline Mfg. Co., 379 Mass.proposition: Violation of statutes and regulations designed to protect the safety of building occupants, including fire and building codes pertaining to smoke detectors, constitutes evidence of negligence.
LaClair v. Silberline Mfg. Co., 379 Mass.case_name: LaClair v. Silberline Manufacturing Co., Inc.
LaClair v. Silberline Mfg. Co., 379 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion does not deal with building or fire code violations, smoke detectors, or statutes/regulations governing safety of building occupants. Instead, it holds that violation of the compulsory workers’ compensation insurance statute is evidence of negligence regarding failure to obtain that insurance. While it recites the general rule that violation of a safety statute is evidence of negligence, the concrete application is limited to workers’ compensation coverage, not building safety codes or smoke detectors, so it does not specifically support the proposition claimed.
LaClair v. Silberline Mfg. Co., 379 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “As has been frequently stated, a violation of a safety statute or like enactment, while not conclusive on the ultimate issue of civil liability, is evidence of a violator’s negligence as to all consequences that the statute was intended to prevent. Perry v. Medeiros, 369 Mass. 836, 841 (1976). Underlying this rule is the general belief that the duties imposed by legislatively-prescribed conduct are normally reasonable ones to bear.”

Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.raw_text: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780 (2007)
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.proposition: Even if Defendant is deemed not to have had actual notice, Defendant had constructive notice of the defective condition because the low-battery chirping persisted for an extended period and because a reasonable inspection of the common hallway area would have revealed that the detector was inoperative and missing its battery.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.support_reasoning: The proposition is about constructive notice based on a persistently chirping, inoperative smoke detector and what a reasonable inspection of a common hallway would have revealed. Sheehan concerns a slip-and-fall on a grape in a supermarket and addresses constructive notice only in the context of floor hazards and then replaces that traditional notice analysis with the mode-of-operation doctrine. It does not discuss building safety devices, low-battery chirping, common areas, or inspections revealing an inoperative detector, so it provides no authority for the specific constructive notice theory described in the proposition.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.relevant_excerpt: “Historically, Massachusetts has also followed the traditional approach governing premises liability… This court has thus held that premises liability attaches only if a store owner has actual or constructive notice of the existence of the dangerous condition, sufficient to allow time for the owner to remedy the condition… Of the two modern approaches, the mode of operation and burden-shifting approaches, the mode of operation approach is in our view the more preferable, and we now adopt it.”

Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.raw_text: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165 (1973)
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.proposition: Even if Defendant is deemed not to have had actual notice, Defendant had constructive notice of the defective condition because the low-battery chirping persisted for an extended period and because a reasonable inspection of the common hallway area would have revealed that the detector was inoperative and missing its battery.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.support_reasoning: The case concerns slip-and-fall liability from a foreign substance on stairs in a subway station, not building code duties or smoke detector maintenance. It discusses when a possessor of land has constructive notice of a transient hazardous condition based on how long it has been present and employee proximity, but it does not involve alarms, batteries, or inspections of a common hallway for inoperative detectors. While it sets out a general constructive-notice framework, it does not specifically support the proposition about constructive notice from prolonged low-battery chirping or a missing smoke-detector battery.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.relevant_excerpt: “Where a foreign substance on a floor or stairway causes the business visitor to fall and sustain injuries, he may prove the negligence of the defendant by proof that the defendant or his servant caused the substance to be there, or he may show that the defendant or his servants had actual knowledge of the existence of the foreign substance… In the more usual case, however, the plaintiff attempts to establish the defendant’s negligence by showing that the foreign substance was present on the defendant’s premises for such a length of time that the defendant should have known about it.”

Lindsey v. Massios, 372 Mass. 79 (1977).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landlord may be held liable where its negligence in maintaining building safety features contributes to a tenant’s injuries.
Lindsey v. Massios, 372 Mass. 79 (1977).support_reasoning: The court explicitly holds that a landlord owes tenants’ visitors a duty of reasonable care in maintaining common areas under its control, and that violation of safety statutes (such as lighting requirements) constitutes evidence of negligence. The opinion rejects the older, more restrictive rule and states that a landlord’s duty of reasonable care extends to all lawful visitors, including tenants’ guests, specifically in the context of maintaining building safety features like lighting and stairways. This directly supports landlord liability where negligent maintenance of safety features contributes to a tenant’s injuries.
Lindsey v. Massios, 372 Mass. 79 (1977).relevant_excerpt: “Therefore, we no longer follow the common law rule that a landlord owes to his tenants’ visitors the same duty he owes to his tenants concerning the maintenance of common passageways in his control. … The landowner’s duty of reasonable care in maintaining property he controls extends to all lawful visitors on his premises, including the lawful visitors of his tenants. … If Massios violated a statutory duty concerning safe maintenance of common passageways within her control, such a violation is evidence of negligence which the jury may consider.”

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landlord may be held liable where its negligence in maintaining building safety features contributes to a tenant’s injuries.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The case deals with a landlord’s liability for rent abatement under the implied warranty of habitability when heat and hot water are not provided, expressly in a context where there was insufficient evidence of intentional, negligent, or bad‑faith conduct by the landlord. It does not address personal injury or tort liability, nor does it hold that a landlord may be liable for tenant injuries due to negligent maintenance of safety features. The discussion of tort liability is expressly distinguished from the warranty/rent‑abatement context and is not a holding imposing negligence-based personal injury liability.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The Superior Court judge found there was insufficient evidence to conclude that the landlord acted intentionally, negligently, or in bad faith. He found and ruled that the losses of heat and hot water were material breaches of the warranty of habitability… The landlord relies in part on case law relating to tort liability for injuries caused by failure to repair defective premises. We have held that, when the defect occurs in the common areas, the landlord is subject to a duty of reasonable care…. When the defect occurs in the rented premises, the question is not one of negligence, but one of breach of warranty.”

Colter v. Barber\u2011Greene Co., 403 Ma.proposition: To the extent any comparative negligence is alleged, Plaintiff’s negligence, if any, was not greater than the negligence of Defendant, and any recovery should be diminished only in proportion to her alleged fault under G.L. c. 231, § 85.
Colter v. Barber\u2011Greene Co., 403 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion directly discusses the operation of Massachusetts’ comparative negligence statute, G.L. c. 231, § 85, in negligence actions. It explains that a plaintiff’s contributory negligence does not bar recovery unless it is greater than the total negligence of defendants, and that otherwise recovery is diminished in proportion to the plaintiff’s fault. That aligns with the proposition that any comparative negligence reduces but does not bar recovery if plaintiff’s negligence is not greater than defendant’s.
Colter v. Barber\u2011Greene Co., 403 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “In a negligence case, the conduct of the plaintiff which will serve to bar recovery is governed by statute. Our comparative negligence statute provides that the plaintiff's contributory negligence shall not bar recovery if the plaintiff's negligence was not greater than the total amount of negligence attributable to the parties against whom recovery is sought. The plaintiff's negligence, if less than the amount attributable to the defendant or defendants, only serves to diminish recovery by the proportion of negligence attributable to the plaintiff. G.L. c. 231, § 85 (1986 ed.).”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: To the extent any comparative negligence is alleged, Plaintiff’s negligence, if any, was not greater than the negligence of Defendant, and any recovery should be diminished only in proportion to her alleged fault under G.L. c. 231, § 85.

Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540 (19.proposition: Defendant is liable to Plaintiff for all damages proximately caused by its negligence under Massachusetts law.
Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion does not articulate any general rule that a negligent defendant is liable for all damages proximately caused under Massachusetts law. Instead, it addresses specific, more limited tort issues: recoverability for negligent infliction of emotional distress, wrongful-life–type bar where the plaintiff’s existence depends on the drug, prenatal injury claims, and market-share liability. The court never states or applies a broad proximate-cause damages principle of the sort described in the proposition, so this case is not proper authority for that general rule.

Clohessy v. Bachelor, 46 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Clohessy v. Bachelor, 46 Mass. App. Ct. 636 (1999)
Clohessy v. Bachelor, 46 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Defendant is liable to Plaintiff for all damages proximately caused by its negligence under Massachusetts law.
Clohessy v. Bachelor, 46 Mass. App. Ct..case_name: Money Store/Massachusetts, Inc. v. Hingham Mutual Fire Insurance
Clohessy v. Bachelor, 46 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion is an insurance/mortgagee priority case about an insurer’s obligations under a standard mortgage clause and the effect of subrogation and assignment; it does not address the general tort principle that a negligent defendant is liable for all damages proximately caused under Massachusetts law. The court analyzes contractual rights between insurer and mortgagees, not negligence, causation, or scope of tort damages. Therefore it does not provide authority for the broad proposition stated.
Clohessy v. Bachelor, 46 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: "In consequence of the contractual relation between an insurer and a mortgagee under the standard mortgage clause, the insurer is obliged to pay the debts due listed mortgagees to the extent of the loss or the policy limits, whichever is higher.... As both Chicopee Savings Bank and Money Store were listed in the Hingham Mutual policy and had mortgage balances due them at the time of the explosion and fire, both were entitled to policy proceeds to the extent of the loss."

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Pre‑judgment and post‑judgment interest as allowed by law, including pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B;

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60.proposition: Plaintiff demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable as of right pursuant to the laws of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, including G.L. c. 231, § 60.
